subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Reading practice - The Raven
msgSnippet: ... Actually, having been to graduate school in literature, there is a huge debate on whether you should represent what the author wrote. Without getting into
messageBody:
Paul wrote:
>


> Makes sense to me, but the copy I have from Gutenberg has them
> separated, and if that's how Poe wrote it, who am I to edit? Of
> course, if that's not how he wrote it, I need to change it, so I
> will check a few sources.

Actually, having been to graduate school in literature, there is a huge
debate on whether you should represent what the author wrote. Without
getting into all that nonsense, I think you should just write what makes
the most sense and looks right (which printers follow for most works of
literature, anyway).

>
> "or" would make more sense in the sentence, but "and" is what is in
> my copy from Gutenberg. I had to double check after I read your note.


That must be a mistake. "And" makes no sense, and I also downloaded a
version from Gutenberg and saw the words was "or." There is more than
one version on Gutenberg, I believe. Hold on, let me see if I have any
Poe around...Nope. no luck.


spell the "not" in cannot with "Ah." I
> >expected "Awl."
>
> Again, that's just how I say it. Rhymes with Trent "Lott", or "Mott"
> The Hoople

Mott the Hoople? What the hey!

What translation software did you use? I have written my own, but it
doesn't make sense to have different versions of the same thing. The
challenge for translation software is having a good dictionary to read
from. I am starting to build one slowly, using a huge 100,000 word one I
downloaded, and making changes to it as I go along. I just mention this
because we could all contribute a little bit to this word base.

On another note, reading "The Raven" made me wish for more uniform
spelling so the reading didn't go so slow. It took me a long time to
read this--kind of frustrating, because when I looked at the one in TO I
breezed right through. Reading 20,000 leagues all in QS would be a
herculean task for me right now. If you do undertake this project, let
me know. It would make a lot more sense for you to store the project on
the sourceforge place. There are enormous advantages to doing it that
way. You "commit" your work every time you work on it and can revert to
any previous version if you have to (and we usually do!), and you won't
ever lose anything. Plus we could typeset it in Tex, which makes
managing such a big project easier. For a small transliterations, all
this geek crap isn't needed--but for a bigger one, it could really save
you headaches.

Thanks for posting this poem. I am going to add it to my collection of
texts, and when I fix the mistakes that you agree are mistakes I'll also
post a PDF version on the Yahoo site.

Paul
